fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I was invited to participate in the Kakehashi Project between Feb. 4–11. Enormous thanks to Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Consulate-General of Japan in Detroit, and my many Japanese language instructors at Michigan for this opportunity, which comes from winning the MJSC last year!
Tremendous thanks again to Ayaka Sogabe. It seems there's no end to all the things (and more) for which I have to thank her.

Since ceasing to return again and again to Skyrim, I have found that I return again and again to a desire to study Anglo-Saxon, for which I had taken a class a couple of years ago as a sophomore at Michigan. There were five or six of us enrolled,Mostly, from what I recall, seniors in the German department; though this is probably really inaccurate. But the best student seemed to be a Middle-Eastern studies fellow. though on a typical day only three or four might show up to class, which centered mostly around reading and modernising texts in Moore and Knott's The Elements of Old English, 10th ed. There was some discussion of sound changes which I've entirely forgotten. It was sometimes a slog, sometimes great fun, and anyways it has been difficult to keep up since then, however much I would like. In recent weeks I've been slowly working through An Introduction to Old English.The power of the interlibrary loan is not to be understated. It's proven to be, in many ways, substantially more digestible.

I could complain much about the textbooks and the other resources, but probably, at the end of the day, I just don't practice it enough. So here's to more practice,And to work these sidenotes to the limit. by glossing and modernising the famous "The Battle of Brunanburh", the only poem I've worked through in its entirety in the past. The text is the edition in the OEPF, edited by Martin Foys. I suppose I can compare with Tennyson's afterwards.

fr:title.text: A somewhat and poorly glossed "The Battle of Brunanburh"

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A somewhat and poorly glossed "The Battle of Brunanburh"

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Parts I don't yet know how to gloss are left as '...'; they'll get filled in as time goes on...Probably.

html:span.fr:p:
Heradv. which can mean 'here', but in this case is probably closer to 'in this year'. Æþelstan cyning,nom. sg. masc. n. cyning, 'king'. eorla dryhten,gen. pl. masc. n. eorl, 'earl'. nom. sg. masc. n. dryhten, 'lord'.
beorna beahgifa,gen. pl. masc. n. beorn, 'warrior' (poet.). nom. sg. masc. n. bēahgifa, 'ring-giver'; bēah + gifa. and his broþor3 gen. sg. masc. pron., 'his'. nom. sg. masc. n. brōþor, 'brother'. eac,
Eadmund æþeling,nom. sg. masc. n. æþeling, 'noble'; æþel + ing (dim. suf.). ealdorlangne tiracc. sg. masc. adj. ealdorlang, 'life-long'; ealdor + lang; mod. tir. acc. s.g masc. n. tīr, 'glory'.
geslogon... æt sæccedat. sg. fem. n. sæc, 'conflict'. sweorda ecgumgen. pl. neut. n. sweord, 'sword'. ins. pl. fem. n. ecg, 'edge'.
ymbe Brunanburh. Bordweal clufan, ›

‹ ymbe Brunanburh. Bordwealnom. sg. masc. n. bordweal, 'shield-wall'; bord + weal. clufan,...
heowan... heaþolindeacc. pl. fem. n. heaþolind, 'linden war-shield' hamora lafan,gen. pl. masc. n. hamor, 'hammer'. ins.(?) pl. fem. n. lāf, 'remains, legacy' (poet. usage). The phrase hamora lafan refers to swords, which are made by hammers.
afaran Eadweardes,3 pl. pret. ind. str. vi vb. āfaran, 'to depart, march out'. gen. sg. masc. n. Eadweard, 'Edward'; gen. of source(?). swa him geæþele wæs3 dat. pl. masc. pron. 'them'. .... 3 sg. pret. ind. anom. vb. bēon, 'to be'.
from cneomægum,dat. pl. masc. n. *cnēomǣg, 'relation, kindred'; cnēomǣgas is attested. þæt hi æt campe3 nom. pl. masc. pron. 'they'. prep. 'at'. dat. sg. masc. n. camp, 'battle'. oft
wiþ laþra gehwæne... land ealgodon,acc. sg. neut. n. land, 'land'. 3 pl. pret. ind. wk. 2 vb. ealgian, 'to defend'.
hord and hamas.acc. sg. masc. n. hord, 'hoard'. conj. 'and'. acc. pl. masc. n. hām, 'home'. Hettend crungun, ›

‹ hord and hamas. Hettend crungun,nom. pl. masc. n. hettend (str. nd-stem), 'enemy'. 3 pl. pret. ind. str. iiia vb. cringan, 'fall, yield'.
Sceotta leodagen. pl. masc. n. Sceottas (str. n-stem), 'the Scots (the Irish)'; of leoda. gen. pl. masc. n. lēod, 'prince'; of Hettend(?). and scipflotannom. pl. wk. masc. n. sċipflota, 'sailor'.
fæge feollan,nom. pl. masc. str. adj. fǣġe, 'fey, doomed to die'. 3 pl. pret. ind. str. vii vb. feallan, 'to fall'. feld dennadenom. sg. masc. n. feld, 'field'. 3 sg. pret. ind. wk. 2 vb. dennian, 'to become slippery'.
secga swate,gen. pl. masc. n. seċġ, 'warrior' (poet. usage). dat.(?) sg. masc. swāt, 'blood'. siðþan sunne upconj. 'since'. nom. sg. wk. fem. n. sunne, 'sun'. adv. 'up'.
on morgentid,prep. w. acc., 'on, during'. acc. sg. fem. n. morġentīd, 'morning-tide'; morġen + tīd. mære tungol,acc. sg. neut. str. adj. mǣre, 'renowned'; of tungol. acc. sg. neut. n. tungol, 'heavenly body, star'; app. sunne.
glad ofer grundas,3 sg. pret. ind. str. i vb. glīdan, 'to glide, slip'. prep. w. acc. indicating motion from above. acc. pl. masc. n. grund, 'ground'. godes condel beorht,gen. sg. masc. n. gōd, 'God'. nom. sg. fem. n. condel, 'candel'. nom. sg. fem. str. adj. beorht, 'bright'.
eces drihtnes,gen. sg. masc. str. adj. ēce, 'eternal, perpetual'. gen. sg. masc. n. drihten, 'lord'; of godes. oð sio æþele gesceaftconj. 'until'. nom. sg. fem. def. art. nom. sg. fem. wk. adj. æþele, 'noble, eminent'. nom. sg. fem. n. gesceaft, 'the creation'.
sah to setle.3 sg. pret. ind. str. i vb. sīgan, 'to sink, fall'. prep. w. dat. 'to'. dat. sg. masc./neut. n. setl, 'seat, residence'. Þær læg secg mænig ›

‹ sah to setle. Þær læg secg mænigadv. 'there'. 3 sg. pret. ind. str. v vb. liċġan, 'to lie'. nom. sg. masc. n. seċġ, 'man' (poet.). adj. w. sg. n. 'many'; of secg.
garum ageted,ins. pl. masc. n. gar, 'spear, arms'. pp. wk. 1 vb. agetan, 'to destroy'. guma norþernanom. sg. wk. masc. n. guma, 'man'; of secg mænig. nom. sg. mas. wk. adj. norþerne, 'northern'.
ofer scild scoten,prep. w. acc. 'over'. acc. sg. masc. n. sċild, 'shield'. pp. str. ii vb. sċēotan, 'to shoot'; of secg mænig, guma. swilce Scittisc eac,adv. 'as, like'. nom. pl. masc. undecl.(?) adj. Scittisc, 'Scottish (Irish)'. adv. 'also, too'.
werig, wiges sæd.nom. sg. masc. str. adj. weriġ, 'weary, tired'. gen. sg. masc. n. wīg, 'war, battle' (poet.). nom. sg. masc. str. adj. sǣd, 'sated, weary'. Wesseaxe forð ›

‹ werig, wiges sæd. Wesseaxe forðdat. sg. masc. n. Wesseaxe, 'Wessex'. adv. 'forth, thence'.
ondlongne dægacc. sg. neut. str. adj. ondlong, 'all-along, throughout'. acc. sg. masc. n. dæg, 'day'. eorodcistumdat. pl. fem. n. ēorodcist, 'company, troop'.
on last legdunprep. w. dat./ins. expressing .... dat.(?) sg. masc. n. lāst, 'footstep, track'. 3 pl. pret. ind. wk. 1 vb. leċġan, 'to slay'(?). laþum þeodumdat. pl. fem. adj. lāþ, 'hateful, evil'. dat. pl. fem. n. þeōd, 'nation, people'.,
heowan herefleman3 pl. pret. ind. str. vii vb. hēawan, 'to strike, chop'. acc. pl. masc. n. hereflēma, 'one who flees from battle'. hindan þearleadv. 'from behind'. adv. 'severely, sorely'.
mecum mylenscearpan.ins. pl. masc. n. mēce, 'sword, falchion'. ins. pl. masc. adj. mylenscearp, 'ground sharp'; str. decl. mylenscearpum in some MS. Myrce ne wyrndon ›

‹ mecum mylenscearpan. Myrce ne wyrndonnom. pl. masc. n. Myrce, 'The Mercians'. 3 pl. pret. ind. wk. 2 vb. wyrnan, 'to keep from, refuse'; in this case w. gen. of what is prohibited.
heardes hondplegangen. sg. masc. adj. heard, 'hard, harsh'. gen. sg. masc. n. honplega, 'hand-play'. hæleþa nanum
þæra þe mid Anlafe ofer æra gebland
on lides bosme land gesohtun,
fæge to gefeohte. Fife lægun

‹ fæge to gefeohte. Fife lægun
on þam campstede cyningas giunge,
sweordum aswefede, swilce seofene eac
eorlas Anlafes, unrim heriges,
flotan and Sceotta. Þær geflemed wearð
Norðmanna bregu, nede gebeded,
to lides stefne litle weorode;
cread cnear on flot, cyning ut gewat
on fealene flod, feorh generede.
Swilce þær eac se froda mid fleame com
on his cyþþe norð, Costontinus,
har hildering, hreman ne þorfte
mæca gemanan; he wæs his mæga sceard,
freonda gefylled on (his) folcstede,
beslagen æt sæcce, and his sunu forlet
on wælstowe wundun fergrunden,
giungne æt guðe. Gelpan ne þorfte
beorn blandenfeax bilgeslehtes,
eald inwidda, ne Anlaf þy ma;
mid heora herelafum hlehhan ne þorftun
þæt heo beaduweorca beteran wurdun
on campstede cumbolgehnastes,
garmittinge, gumena gemotes,
wæpengewrixles, þæs hi on wælfelda
wiþ Eadweardes afaran plegodan.
Gewitan him þa Norþmen nægledcnearrum,
dreorig daraða laf, on Dinges mere
ofer deop wæter Difelin secan,
eft Iraland, æwiscmode.
Swilce þa gebroþer begen ætsamne,
cyning and æþeling, cyþþe sohton,
Wesseaxena land, wiges hremige.
Letan him behindan hræw bryttian
saluwigpadan, (and) þone sweartan hræfn,
hyrnednebban, and þane hasewanpadan,
earn æftan hwit, æses brucan,
græ- -digne guðhafoc and þæt græge deor,
wulf on wealde. Ne wearð wæl mare
on þis eiglande æfer gieta
folces gefylled beforan þissum
sweordes ecgum, þæs þe us secgað bec,
ealde uðwitan, siþþan eastan hider
Engle and Seaxe up becoman,
ofer brad brimu Brytene sohtan,
wlance wigsmiþas, Weala s ofercoman,
eorlas arhwate eard begeatan.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: I'm a first year doctoral student at Brown University, advised by Nikos Vasilakis and Robert Lewis. My interests are in programming languages, especially type theory, proof assistants, and formal verification. I'm also supported by the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship.

Previously, I was an undergraduate in computer science at The University of Michigan, where I worked with Cyrus Omar in the Future of Programming Lab. I was also the Communications Chair of the Japanese Language Circle for some time.

Happy to say that I was able to pass this past December's edition of the JLPT N1 with 142/180—pretty good, all things considered. A very big thanks to all my instructors at Michigan, especially Ayaka Sogabe, Masae Yasuda, Yoshihiro Mochizuki, Junko Kondo, Yamato Kitahashi, and Yoshimi Sakakibara!
I was the undergraduate teaching assistant for EECS 490 for the 2023-2024 year.

fr:blockquote.fr:p: Programming languages are rich mathematical structures and powerful user interfaces. This course covers the design and use of modern programming languages. We will build up systematically from formal first principles while considering human factors in language design, language prototyping, and techniques for reasoning precisely about program behavior throughout the course.

The goal is to change the way you think about programming and programming language design in ways that will remain relevant across the many technology hype cycles that you will encounter over the course of your careers.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The course was lectured by Cyrus Omar; Andrew Blinn and David Moon were the graduate teaching assistants in F23 and W24, respectively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:blockquote: FP Lab at the The University of Michigan designs next-generation user interfaces for modern programming languages. Our research runs the methodological gamut, ranging from type-theoretic foundations through to human-centered design. We are particularly interested in applications to computer science education, accessibility, computational and data science, formal verification, and computational creativity.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A space for semiweekly Japanese language conversation practice.

I was the Communications Chair (I sent emails + stuff) for the 2023–2024 academic year, succeeding the delightful Jack Gisondi. We met in room 2022 of the South Thayer Building on Monday and Thursday evenings from 7 PM (and ending any time between 8 PM and 2 AM).

Recurring topics apparently included mushrooms and the vegetable-or-not status of potatoes, and we also had some events—board games, origami, calligraphy, and so on. Afterwards, Suparna Hande bore this honorable torch before passing it on.
